channel.title: Wickerbox
channel.description: Adventures of an aerospace geek in Portland, Oregon.

item.title: GetPixels
item.description:
GetPixels converts an image to a text file of grayscale pixel values and reconstructs the image. I wrote it so I could manipulate the value of an image’s pixels using convolution kernels and easily look at the results.

Find the code at GitHub.

GetPixels is open source software licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike International license. That means you can share and adapt the work for any purpose as long as you give me credit and share your work alike.

Usage

./GetPixels.o <op> <image.png> <pixels.txt> <width> <height>

op is the desired operation. Use ‘1’ for image→pixels and ‘2’ for pixels→image.

image.png is the relative file path to the image and pixels.txt is the text file.

height and width are the values in pixels of the image.

Build

I used OpenCV 2.4.8 and g++ to compile on Linux Mint 15 (Olivia).

Failure Cases

The program will alert you if the height or width is less than 1, if the input image or input pixel file don’t exist, or if the operation chosen is not 1 or 2.

Note: The output files will be created and overwrite any existing files without prompting!

If you give the program a portrait of dimensions 240×320 but you tell the program it’s a landscape of dimensions 320×240, you’ll get a broken reconstruction:

item.title: Strain Gauge Amplifier Board v1
item.description:
Made in collaboration with Andrew Greenberg, who is awesome.

The quarter-bridge design uses the strain gauges as one of the four resistors in a Wheatstone bridge, references the bridge to 2.5V, and runs the output of the bridge through an INA125 Instrumentation Op-Amp IC which actually has three op amps in it. We’re using Euroterminals for the strain gauge input and the sense signal outputs.

This is a non-intuitive approach but bear with me. Everything on the board except the purple reversed lettering is on the top side of the board. The reversed purple lettering is on the bottom. I made the boards on the LPKF router that doesn’t actually make two sides of a hole connect electrically … so we’re soldering all the components, including the legs of the connectors, on the top side. The connectors are actually accessible on the bottom side. Just their pins are sticking through to the top layer.

We’ll turn the top side towards the bamboo carrier and use washers to make space so the components aren’t touching the bamboo.

Using a laser cutter to make the bamboo carrier boards.

Our PCB router. Alas, no time lapse.

This is the top side of the board.

And the bottom side.

What it’ll look like.

All ten boards, ten carrier boards, and the parchment stencil.

item.title: Carbon Fiber Airframe Layup
item.description:
An ME capstone team has built the Portland State Aerospace Society a curing oven and will be giving us an example airframe and developing a process for us to build lots more on our own. It’s epic and will let us make more rockets and, more importantly, make interchangeable rocket modules.

Sam and Robert machine the module end rings.

Jack and Barett prep the rings.

Tung’s cleaning and applying wax liquid hybrid mold release to the cylindrical molds.

Not sure we have the hang of core seams yet…

The mold is waxed and then, in order, we place adhesive, the inside layer of carbon fiber, adhesive, the core, adhesive, the outer layer of carbon fiber, and shrink tape.

It’s pretty cool to see our oven control shield at work. The hacked Ethernet cables connect MAX31855 thermocouple-to-digital ICs over SPI so in v3 we’re definitely putting the ICs on the board, super close to the controller, and buying longer thermocouples to run to the oven.

Ready to bake at 350F for three hours.

item.title: Snow at the Tualatin Refuge
item.description:
Just the other night, the wetland was covered in geese; now it’s ice and slush.

The oak study area under snow.

The human-sized “eagle” nest they built back in summer is holding up nicely.

Continuing on through the Rock Creek study area and along the edge of the open wetland.

Lots of little birds foraging, geese passing overhead, and a hawk keeping an eye out.

There’s a viewing platform over the Tualatin River.

Following the creek around to the wetland. I spent a lot of time playing with lighting. Still not sure I have it.

I think the shapes made by leafless trees are great. Dendrophotography?

item.title: 124km DxWifi Flight Test
item.description:
The antenna setup in the back of the plane. We were all about all these different ways to attach the antenna, internally and externally, but it turned out taping it in the back window was good enough.

Taxiing out and taking off at Troutdale.

Looking northeast towards Camas.

Our most excellent pilot.

Our most excellent antenna operator.

We did a few circles on the Washington side of the river to give the Rocky Butte ground team a chance to get up and running ot see if they could catch our packets. We had no idea if we were going to even be able to make contact.

But we did! And we headed north to the west of Mt St Helens.

We warned the ground team we might lose them for a minute or two and we took a detour to check out the caldera.

We ended up spending a lot of time circling over Morton, WA, but that was about where our signal problems started. We did continue on to Kapowsin Field, right at the edge of Seattle airspace, at about 10,000 feet.

On the way back south, we moved the antenna to the front right window but we couldn’t shake the communication problems. We lost both SMS and radio to Rocky Butte so when we turned around the ground team wasn’t entirely sure where we were and we weren’t ever really able to re-establish contact. The antennas have a very narrow beam over which they can receive so if we had to be exactly where the Rocky Butte team was pointing their antenna, and for the most part we weren’t.

We were also considering fuel/range issues and ended up deciding to just head back to Troutdale and call it a win.

On final to Troutdale, with bonus propellers. (It’s actually not really possible with iPhone to take a picture out the front window that doesn’t catch the prop.)

Our pilot puts the plane away.

item.title: Oven Control Board v2
item.description:
I worked with Tung as part of the ME capstone team at Portland State to update the oven controller Arduino shield I made last week. Tung had already updated the Eagle schematic so this time for me it was just layout, routing, and basic soldering. I fixed the one via problem but then promptly made the same mistake on the other set of headers, so I delivered the board last night and it should work fine but the soldering was trickier than I’d like.

I’m still so spoiled by having OSHPark. The only Gerbers I give our lab’s LPKF router are the Top Layer, Bottom Layer, Board Outline, and Unplated Drill. No silkscreen. I could solder mask but I haven’t. Maybe next time. I used materials and headers I had on hand but even through OSHPark it’d be just under $30 for three boards.

Here are the schematic, layout, and final photos. Eagle files are on the Github repo.

item.title: 1 Feb 2014
item.description:
I was a little bummed this morning that January’s over and I don’t have any other hardware stuff to post about but I realized that I’ve been super busy doing, you know, work for which I’m paid and can’t talk about. On the hobby hacking side, I’ve done plenty of work this month between the oven controller, a couple of GPS RF board design reviews, the DxWiFi test, and my BJJ habit. I’ve also had four sessions of EPL managing where other people came in to work on stuff.

One of my biggest reasons for having the site is to remind myself that I do things by posting pictures of the stuff I do. I tend to forget and then blame myself for being Not Productive Enough.

So looking back, I’m delighted to remember that I had a really enjoyable January.

item.title: 28 Jan 2014
item.description:
My library flow for Eagle is to work out of a single directory called ~/.eagle and have all my libraries, scripts, etc. to be in there. Anything that would be used by multiple designs.

I never, ever, ever use the epf files and I’ve yet to meet anybody who does.

To start a new design, I make a repo on Github and clone it to my dev machine. I create a schematic and start working. At some point I’ll make the board and work on that. Any changes to libraries happens in that default directory.

When I’m reading to commit, I use the Eagle export function to create multiple library files into a local folder called ‘lbr’ or ‘libraries’ so anybody who forks the repo has all the parts they need.

When I git pull, I always check if I got updated libraries and I’ll wrap them back into my default library. I’m pretty sure I’m running the risk of losing work in the overwriting/copying process but I’m kind of stuck on what to do about it, except be very careful.

Eagle’s libraries are basically just frustrating as hell.
